However, although folate is the most important determinant of plasma homocyst(e)ine, there is clearly also an inverse relation between cobalamin and plasma homocyst(e)ine (1). Pernicious anemia is the most common cause of cobalamin deficiency (2), and because the plasma homocyst(e)ine level is elevated in more than 95% of patients with pernicious anemia (3), an increased risk for cardiovascular disease might reasonably be expected in patients with pernicious anemia if an elevated homocyst(e)ine level is truly causally associated with an increased risk ...References1.
